Thanks to you for sharing this with all of us. By doing you help turn your own pain and doubt and insecurity into a source of connection with other humans who are suffering. In that, you are passing on love.

For me, you've already "beaten" the leukemia. Now I just wish for you a complete healing in your body. Your heart is already in a good place.

Isn't it time for us to say "Okay... you win... I quit... but I'm not going to pay the rent on the playing field anymore."?  Alexander the Great, et al., learned, the hard way, that Afghanistan and Pakistan were not worth it.  Must we be forever condemned to relive history?

there weren't trenches in WWII and the fighting on the western front for the Germans, French and British was over in 6 weeks at the beginning of the war.  The Americans fought for nearly a year from D Day on so it would be interesting to find out their head injury rates as well as the Germans who fought the Russians for 4 years on the eastern front. It would interesting to find out German and Russian statistics. No matter what they are it's a safe bet they were underreported and no attempts to correlate with postwar depression/drug abuse/suicide were ever made.

It doesn't mean much. I saw people redeployed for their third and fourth year-long combat tours who shouldn't have been sent on their second. But given the number of troops required, without instituting a Draft, all you can do is send the same people back two or more times each. This was supposedly doing war "on the cheap."

It doesn't look like it will turn out to be so cheap after all.

The problem is that there is nothing relevant that an MRI can tell us. That is why we have to wait until people die to examine their brains under a microscope. If we could diagnose these injuries with MRI or other imaging tool, it would be much easier to study. These injuries are not visible to any imaging technique.

Barney,

If you're going to assume the role of the enlightened educator, please be responsible enough to get your basic facts straight. For instance, the gold plates translated by Joseph Smith were a "purported" compilation of ancient texts compiled by a prophet named Mormon (hence the name), who delivered them to his son Moroni. Moroni hid the plates at the end of his life, later revealing them to Joseph Smith. I understand you do not believe this to be true and I don't judge you for it. Though I do believe it to be true, neither the story nor the physical evidence -or lack thereof- have led me to this conclusion. Therefore, I empathize with you, as you have not been convinced by the story or the evidence either.

Now, if you're going to defame us by revealing our zany beliefs, please be courteous enough to reveal things we actually believe. You won't have a hard time finding any, go to lds.org and take them straight from the source. Read a page or two from the book you hope to discredit, you'll be much more credible, I promise. You don't need to make things up or stretch the truth. We have peculiar beliefs, they're weird enough on their own, so please be accurate.

Thank you,

F.W. Willis

Good piece, Patrick Devaney! After all, net wealth in the form of real estate is taxed (property tax). Should apply to all wealth equally (stocks etc).

Also, real estate transfers like home sales are taxed. Transfers of stocks should be taxed too. That would dampen some of the irrational exuberance (including fraud) in stock sales.

These two things could be done before the major overhaul that you are discussing. Good luck, and don't stop advocating!

For the record, Mormons do not believe that "the god of this world lives on the planet of Kolob." We also don't consider ourselves to be "polytheists", though that is certainly a matter for a long theological debate. Simply stating it as fact here, instead of your opinion, is potentially misleading and certainly leaves out a lot of important details. It seems like you include it (and the Kolob jab) here in an effort to show that you believe Romney is different in a way that makes you uncomfortable.

The Kolob thing gets repeated a lot on the Internet, but it is a mistatement of an obscure point of doctrine that most Mormons couldn't possible care less about.

As F.W. Willis points out (below), we have enough interesting beliefs that you don't need to make up new ones or stretch the truth about real ones.

Dale Lawton: I don't believe that Romney is different in a way that makes me uncomfortable. I believe all kinds of weird things, including the doctrine of the Trinity and the Real Presence. Metaphysics is weird.

I am just pointing out that Americans are not interested in theology. Politically, religion has become a proxy for a moral code. Conservatives couldn't give a hoot whether a candidate believes there is one God, no God or many gods: they just want a candidate who supports sex roles and a restrictive code of sexual conduct. I don't give a hoot what anyone's metaphysical commitments are, whether they believe the god of this world lives on Kolob or in Hackensack, New Jersey. I just care that they oppose sex roles and support the creation of a welfare state.

I don't dislike Mormons because of their theology. Theology is an entertainment. I dislike them because of the socially conservative lifestyle they support.

Of course! Let's get real. Evangelicals for the most part don't care about fine, or even coarse, points of metaphysical doctrine. They care about sexuality, sex roles, and "family values." They will have no problem voting for a socially conservative Mormon any more than they had a problem with a socially conservative Catholic like Rick Santorum--who many believed was an Evangelical. Theology proper--metaphysical doctrines concerning the existence and nature of God doesn't matter to them.

So they would certainly prefer a polytheistic Mormon who believes the god of this world lives on the planet of Kolob or a Catholic who owes allegiance to a bishop who their ancestors identified with the Antichrist, than a theologically orthodox Episcopalian (like me) who recites the Nicene Creed every week, and means it. And I would bet that they would prefer an atheist who, perhaps of socio-biological grounds, supported a restrictive code of sexual conduct and sex roles, to a religious believer who didn't.

And my final prophecy is that Evangelicals realize that Obama isn't a Muslim, and discover that conservative Islam is puritanical and sexist, they will join with conservative Muslims to combat sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll, and to promote patriarchy.

"replace the blind clipped winged governance agencies with people who are eager to" do the job. my question to you, sir, and to everybody who agrees with this point (as do I) is whether you're willing to shoulder your share of the tax burden necessary to pay for the people who are eager and willing to do the job? it's been my experience that people often cry out for government intervention (help, assistance, etc) whenever they're faced with a crisis. but when the bill comes due to pay for such intervention (taxes), people begin to assail government employees as being overpaid, benefits-rich, underworked bureacrats. like everything in life, one gets what one pays for.

Gramn-Leach-Bliliey must be repealed! Glass-Steagall needs to be brought back with a vengeance and bring an end to this false economy! And replace the blind clipped winged governance agencies with people who are eager to, incented to, not politically road blocked and capable of doing the job. There is no downside risk for the executives and traders on house accounts. There is no downside risk for the executives and traders who defraud investors with misrepresented securities. There is only an upside risk. So why not bet all of the firm’s and the investor’s money and crash the world economy? If the executives and traders get away with the fraud, the individuals get paid millions of dollars, if they don’t get away with it they get paid less millions of dollars (sometimes). What they should get is jail sentences and personal fines in the millions of dollars.

So timely, Nick. I just got back from a 5-day backpacking trip -- and there is no better way to go off the grid than to get into the wilderness. Being in PR is likely just as bad as being a journalist when it comes to knowing what awaits when you return. I was just thinking about this whole issue this morning and came up with 2 things: 1. it'd be great if cell phone companies gave you an "out of office" option for text messages; and 2. I think it's almost impossible in this day to truly eliminate the "what's waiting for you" syndrome. We have to "combat" it instead by setting expectations both while we're on the grid as well as off it... training people to know that "instant responses" aren't always possible (when you're "on the grid") and not to expect responses right away if you're returning to being back from "off the grid." For those urgent work matters (ie, a journalist or client emailing!), that's why I work with a team I can trust - and I do the same for them when they go off the grid. For non-work/life-issues, my friends get it and know I still love them.

ps. Loved The Goonies (hey you guuyyys!). Also up there is The Lost Boys.

It's reprehensible that a campaign worker attempted to physically block the reporters from leaving their area. Say what you will about the media, reporters are first and foremost citizens of the US (those who are) and absent security concerns can go wherever the heck they want to go, even, and especially, a public rope line.

More and more, Republicans prove the truism that those who scream "The Constitution!" the loudest have the least respect for it and understanding of it.
